title: We're all flawed when it comes to fine print
text:
Our over-reliance on experts is almost comical. A local study showed 90 per cent of consumers who got retirement advice rated it as “good” despite ASIC assessors rating only 3 per cent of the advice given at that level. And when an adviser discloses a conflict, we tend to trust them even more as a result of their candidness.

We’re susceptible to pressure selling, we get overwhelmed by process, and we think companies that advertise regularly, or use a prominent spokesperson, have more credibility.

We struggle with complex disclosure – 64 per cent of consumers couldn’t find all the fees associated with a managed investment in a long-form product disclosure statement (PDS) – but did not do much better with simpler forms. A Monash University experiment with home insurance showed that just 40 per cent consumers who were given a “simple” key fact summary sheet selected objectively the best product, the same rate as those who had read the full PDS.

Features of questionable value

The case studies also highlight how institutions have preyed on consumers' faults.

Products have been loaded with features of questionable value, exposing consumers to nasty surprises when they don't work as expected, and making it difficult to compare one product with another.

Banks promote minimum credit card repayment amounts, even though experiments have shown this can increase the value of overall repayments by as much as 20 per cent – in an effect known as “anchoring” – because consumers let their total debt balloon.

Institutions automatically roll us over in new products with worse conditions to take advantage of our inertia. Some pre-fill complex forms to allow us to make quick and poorly considered decisions.

Advertisement

The report builds on work done in the Murray inquiry and particularly by the Hayne royal commission, which was heavily influenced by the work of Professor Sunita Sah of Cornell University on the many and varied ways in which conflicts emerge.

ASIC commissioner Karen Chester says the point of the study isn’t to diminish that caveat emptor or personal responsibility. Rather, ASIC wants to reinforce how limited disclosure can be and to emphasise that it can't overcome our foibles as consumers.

The key, Chester argues, is the step before disclosure, which is covered under the new design and distribution obligations that were passed by federal parliament in April.

This requires institutions to design and sell products that meet consumer needs, which to Chester means getting rid of unnecessary complexity and what she describes as “sludge” in the system, such as product features that aren’t really needed by the target consumers, as well as poor sales and claims processes.

Get the product design right – and ASIC’s new product intervention powers give the regulator the chance to intervene in the case of those who don’t – and the disclosure should become simpler. For example, it might involve a one-or-two-page summary sheet of a product's key features and risks, which is well written and has been tested to ensure it is leading to the right decisions.

Chester believes this regime is an insurance policy for firms. Design products correctly and get disclosure right, and you’ll avoid the big remediation bills we are seeing now.

And your consumers – with all their very human faults – should thank you for it, too.
description: A new report from the corporate regulator underscores the limits of disclosure and our own foibles as consumers.
